author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Emma Stone, Jesse Plemons and Willem Dafoe Crack the Yorgos Lanthimos Code
description: The stars of his newest film, “Kinds of Kindness” explain that when working with the director, the less you know, the better.
content: In the new Yorgos Lanthimos film “Kinds of Kindness,” a character played by Emma Stone recounts a dream in which she was the denizen of a bizarre world. “There, dogs were in charge,” she murmurs. “People were animals, animals were people.” But being brought to heel by their canine masters wasn’t as bad as it sounds, she says: “I must admit, they treated us pretty well.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 344
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: Choreographer’s ‘Dog Poop Attack’ on a Critic Inspired This New Play
description: At this year’s Theatertreffen drama festival, one production explores an incident that shocked the German theater world last year.
content: On Feb. 11, 2023, the choreographer Marco Goecke cornered a dance critic, Wiebke Hüster, during intermission of a performance at the Hanover State Opera in northern Germany. After asking her about negative reviews that she had written about his past productions, Goecke took out a bag of dog feces and smeared her face with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Litsky and Alex Traub
title: Jim Otto, Hall of Fame Raiders Center, Is Dead at 86
description: Despite his accomplishments on the field, he was remembered mostly for the many beatings his body absorbed, which left him in constant pain.
content: Jim Otto, who played center for 15 years for the Oakland Raiders and underwent more than 70 football-related operations, including the amputation of his right leg, has died. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Avner Gvaryahu
title: Occupation Has Corrupted the Humanity of Israel’s Military
description: There is a disregard among Israeli soldiers for Palestinian lives, and we are seeing it in Gaza today.
content: Israel’s military has brought utter devastation to the Palestinians of Gaza after the attack by Hamas on Oct. 7. But the extreme response is not only a reaction to the horrors of that day. It is also a product of the decades-long role the military has played in enforcing Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: What to Know About Mohammad Mokhber, Iran’s Acting President
description: Mr. Mokhber has long been involved in business conglomerates tied to Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. He must hold elections for a new president within 50 days.
content: With the death of President Ebrahim Raisi, Iran’s first vice president, Mohammad Mokhber, becomes acting president. Mr. Mokhber is a conservative political operative with a long history of involvement in large business conglomerates closely tied to Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: After Raisi’s Death, Speculation Over Succession Turns to Ayatollah’s Son
description: Mojtaba Khamenei, 55,  plays an influential role in the office of the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and has fostered ties within the security apparatus.
content: He is known as a man in the shadows of Iranian politics. Yet Mojtaba Khamenei has a powerful influence over a country that rarely sees or hears him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Iran’s President Died, Opening a New Chapter of Instability
description: Also, prosecutors rested their case against Trump. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Ebrahim Raisi, Iran’s president, was killed yesterday in a helicopter crash along with the country’s foreign minister. A conservative Shiite Muslim cleric, Raisi had a hand in brutal crackdowns on opponents of the Islamic Republic, and he was widely viewed as a possible successor to Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Rise of a New Centrism
description: In Washington, despite polarization, bipartisanship has somehow become normal.
content: Washington, you often hear, is a place so polarized that our leaders barely get anything done. But that notion is not exactly consistent with the past few years. Consider these major political stories:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden and Blinken Accuse I.C.C. Prosecutor of Falsely Equating Israel and Hamas
description: The forceful denunciations of the International Criminal Court came even as tensions have risen between the United States and Israel over its conduct of the war in Gaza.
content: President Biden on Monday condemned the decision by the International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor to seek arrest warrants for two top Israeli officials — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant — when he requested warrants for the leaders of Hamas, saying in a White House statement that “whatever this prosecutor might imply, there is no equivalence — none — between Israel and Hamas.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Scarlett Johansson Said No, but OpenAI’s Virtual Assistant Sounds Just Like Her
description: Last week, the company released a chatbot with an option that sounded like the actress, who provided the voice of an A.I. system in the movie “Her.”
content: Days before OpenAI demonstrated its new, flirty voice assistant last week, the actress Scarlett Johansson said, Sam Altman, the company’s chief executive, called her agent and asked that she consider licensing her voice for a virtual assistant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: The (Very Brief) Return of Gastr del Sol
description: In the ’90s, the duo of Jim O’Rourke and David Grubbs made quiet, intricate music amid a loud rock underground. A new compilation brought them back together.
content: In late January 2016, Akinobu Oda — a Japanese restaurateur and concert promoter — taped a red-and-black handbill demanding “Don’t disturb!!!” to the window of his vegan dive in Tokyo. The reason? The American art-rock band Gastr del Sol was dining inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova, Constant Méheut and Nataliia Novosolova
title: Faced With a Russian Onslaught, Ukraine Struggles to Keep the Lights On
description: The government has for the first time ordered nationwide rolling blackouts for Monday night to conserve energy.
content: As Ukraine struggles to hold back Russian advances, the country’s officials say they are once again facing the formidable challenge of keeping electricity flowing as Moscow’s forces increasingly strike power plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Farnaz Fassihi
title: What We Know About the Helicopter Crash That Killed Iran’s President
description: The deaths of two of Iran’s most high-profile leaders — President Ebrahim Raisi and Foreign Minister Hossein Amir Abdollahian — come at a tumultuous time for the country.
content: The deaths of Iran’s president, Ebrahim Raisi, and foreign minister, Hossein Amir Abdollahian, in a helicopter crash have left one of the Middle East’s most powerful and disruptive nations at a critical moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Sunak Apologizes After Damning Report on U.K. Infected-Blood Scandal
description: A nearly six-year inquiry found that the deaths of about 3,000 people and the infection of more than 30,000 others could have mostly been avoided.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain issued a stark apology on Monday to victims and families of one of the country’s worst health care failures after a damning report found that blood contaminations that killed 3,000 people and infected more than 30,000 others could have been largely avoided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Toobin
title: A Trump Conviction Doesn’t Hang on Michael Cohen
description: As provocative as the testimony has been, this case may turn on something a great deal more mundane.
content: The Manhattan district attorney’s case against Donald Trump has unfolded like a north-of-the-border telenovela, with lurid tales of sex, spankings, hush money and silk pajamas, as well as the occasional detour into the editorial practices of supermarket tabloids. But the case, provocative as it has been, may turn on something a great deal more mundane than the testimony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: 2 Liberal Groups to Spend $5 Million on State Supreme Court Races
description: The National Democratic Redistricting Committee and Planned Parenthood Votes are joining together to help their preferred candidates for 2024 as state-level party battles gain steam.
content: Two groups on the left with differing missions are joining forces to bolster their preferred candidates in state supreme court races in November, as such elections grow increasingly expensive and politically polarizing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Brian X. Chen
title: Can Artificial Intelligence Make the PC Cool Again?
description: Microsoft, HP, Dell and others unveiled a new kind of laptop tailored to work with artificial intelligence. Analysts expect Apple to do something similar.
content: The race to put artificial intelligence everywhere is taking a detour through the good old laptop computer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Paris
title: Renting or Buying Is Often Personal, but It’s Also Helpful to Look at the Numbers
description: The Upshot’s financial calculator has been updated with new features.
content: The Upshot last week updated one of its earliest and most popular projects: the Rent or Buy calculator. Its lasting popularity is no mystery: All of us make this decision at some point. But it may be even more relevant today, with a changed environment of higher interest rates, than it was when the Upshot was created a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A top Biden aide meets with Israeli military officials, and other news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek and Jesse McKinley
title: The Prosecution Rests: Five Takeaways From Trump’s Criminal Trial
description: The judge became furious with a defense witness, and Michael D. Cohen kept his cool.
content: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush-money trial in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Emma Bubola
title: Julian Assange’s Extradition Appeal Hearing: What Could Happen?
description: A hearing on Monday will determine whether Julian Assange has any more recourse in the British courts to appeal his extradition to the United States.
content: Update: A London court ruled on Monday that Julian Assange could appeal his extradition to the United States, a move that extends his long-running legal battle in the British courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: International Criminal Court Prosecutor Requests Warrants for Netanyahu and Hamas Leaders
description: While the request must be approved by the court’s judges, the announcement is a harsh rebuke of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his war strategy in Gaza.
content: The chief prosecutor at the world’s top criminal court on Monday announced that he was seeking arrest warrants for the leaders of both Israel and Hamas on charges of crimes against humanity, a strong rebuke that equated Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with his Hamas counterpart, Yahya Sinwar, and compounded the growing international alarm at Israel’s conduct in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Cannes Meets Trump: ‘The Apprentice’ Sells a Controversial Origin Story
description: The film covers Donald J. Trump’s relationships with the fixer Roy Cohn and his first wife, Ivana, and tries to explain the future president, at least as a young man.
content: Would Donald J. Trump enjoy Cannes? It’s possible, since the extravagant displays of wealth here — all the yachts and glamour — are typically his thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jun Chou and Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet
title: Not Your Grandparents’ Mahjong Table
description: Green Tile Social Club hosted its first tournament, where a younger generation gathered to play an old game and meet new friends.
content: On a drizzly Saturday afternoon, hundreds of mahjong enthusiasts gathered in Downtown Brooklyn to play the 19th-century Chinese game of strategy and luck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Linda Qiu
title: Farm Animals Are Hauled All Over the Country. So Are Their Pathogens.
description: Tens of millions of farm animals cross state lines every year, traveling in cramped, stressful conditions that can facilitate the spread of disease.
content: The bird flu virus that is spreading through American dairy cows can probably be traced back to a single spillover event. Late last year, scientists believe, the virus jumped from wild birds into cattle in the Texas panhandle. By this spring, the virus, known as H5N1, had traveled hundreds of miles or more, appearing on farms in Idaho, North Carolina and Michigan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Matthew Haag
title: Closing Arguments in Trump’s Trial Will Likely Be Next Week, Judge Says
description: Defense lawyers have the opportunity to call witnesses, including their client, former President Donald J. Trump, but whether he will testify is not clear. Then the case goes to the jury.
content: The judge in the criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump said on Monday that the case would take longer than anticipated to wrap up, with closing arguments now not expected until next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Charlie Savage
title: What to Know About the I.C.C. Prosecutor’s Request for Warrants for Israeli and Hamas Leaders
description: The International Criminal Court prosecutor requested arrest warrants for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Hamas leaders. Here is a closer look at the court and the warrant.
content: The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court said on Monday that he had requested arrest warrants for war crimes and crimes against humanity for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the leaders of Hamas. Here’s a closer look at the court and the warrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Russia’s War Machine Revs Up as the West’s Plan to Cap Oil Revenues Sputters
description: Russia has largely evaded attempts by the U.S. and Europe to keep it from profiting from its energy exports.
content: The United States and its allies in the Group of 7 nations set two goals in 2022 when they enacted a novel plan to cap the price of Russian oil: restrict Moscow’s ability to profit from its energy exports while allowing its oil to continue flowing on international markets to prevent a global price shock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Aggression or Caution: The Choice Facing Iran’s Next Leaders
description: The question is whether the successors to the president and foreign minister will take a similar path by keeping slivers of communication open, and avoiding direct conflict with the United States.
content: In their three years in power, President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran and his equally hard-line foreign minister, Hossein Amir Abdollahian, did everything they could to consolidate the “Axis of Resistance” against the United States and Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Top Education Officials Were Warned of FAFSA Overhaul Hurdles in 2020
description: Documents obtained by The Times show the department’s troubled FAFSA rollout this year came in spite of early warnings that the project required sustained attention.
content: Long before the Education Department’s overhaul of the federal student aid application fell apart this year, officials who now lead the department were warned of a complex and time-consuming effort and its potential pitfalls in 2020, according to internal emails and documents obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Wonderful Words: The Winners of Our 11th Annual 15-Second Vocabulary Video Challenge
description: Thank you to the more than 1,200 students who participated this year. Check out the winning videos to learn nine new words.
content: Do you have an aptitude for learning new words? Or, does your hippocampus have trouble retaining fresh vocabulary? But, whether you are oblivious to the pleasures of linguistic mastery, or the thought of expanding your lexicon makes you dyspeptic, we promise that you won’t kvetch after watching these nine clever and informative student videos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Comet Fragment Explodes in Dark Skies Over Spain and Portugal
description: A brilliant flash of blue, green and white on Saturday night came from a shard of an as yet unidentified comet that was moving around 100,000 miles per hour, experts said.
content: On Saturday, revelers across Spain and Portugal ventured into the temperate springtime evening, hoping for a memorable night. None were expecting a visitor from outer space exploding above their heads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: A Different Way of Seeing Justice Alito’s Blame-the-Wife Defense
description: In sickness and health, in public scandal and with convenient finger-pointing.
content: By now, you’ve surely seen the latest round of high-end wife blaming in Washington. In seeking to shift their controversies onto their marital partners, Justice Samuel Alito and Senator Robert Menendez joined a tradition that extends across party lines and stretches back through the centuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Iran’s president is killed in a helicopter crash.
content: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran was killed along with the country’s foreign minister in a helicopter crash yesterday in the country’s mountainous northwest, state news media reported, leaving the country without two of its most influential figures at a time of heightened foreign tensions and domestic discontent. Here’s the latest news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What Does the Dow Hitting 40,000 Tell Us?
description: The stock market isn’t the economy — but its record high refutes conspiracy theories.
content: Last week, for the first time in history, the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 40,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuel Marc Gerecht and Ray Takeyh
title: The Death of Iran’s President Does Not Bode Well
description: The generation on the cusp of taking power in Iran sees domestic oppression and foreign aggression as indispensable to the success of the revolution.
content: Iran’s supreme leader, Ali Khamenei, has not always seen eye to eye with his country’s presidents. Akbar Hashemi-Rafsanjani nudged the Islamic Republic too close to the West for the supreme leader’s liking. Mohammad Khatami rattled the conservative elite with subversive talk of how faith and freedom could coexist. Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was too insubordinate and too populist, while Hassan Rouhani’s flirtation with the Americans and his disappointing arms-control agreement drove him out of the inner circle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: We’re Suddenly Living in a ‘My Wife Did It’ Moment
description: Justice Alito and Senator Menendez have one thing in common.
content: Gail Collins: Gee, Bret, our first presidential debate — coming soon! Next month, in fact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr, Shakked Auerbach, Mark Boyer and Daniel Bateman
title: Back From War, These I.D.F. Soldiers Demand New Leadership
description: Some reservists in the Israel Defense Forces who have returned home from war are joining the growing calls within Israel for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his right-wing coalition to step aside.
content: As the Israel-Hamas war drags into its eighth month, there are loud calls within Israel for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his right-wing coalition to step aside. Among those demanding change are reservists in the Israel Defense Forces — back from the war and now in the streets. The New York Times spoke with three reservists from different political backgrounds to find out why.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Should States Provide Recent High School Graduates With Jobs in Public Service?
description: Maryland has an initiative to help residents find paid work in areas like community development and public health. Tell us if such a program interests you.
content: Do you know what you would like to do after graduating from high school? Are you headed to college with a major in mind or to a training program that will lead to employment in a particular field? Will you join the military, take a gap year or seek full-time work in an area with the hope that it will become your career?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: As New Yorkers Turn on Mayor Adams, Prominent Democrats Join the Pile-On
description: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Jumaane Williams, New York City’s public advocate, criticized the mayor over his management of public housing and campus protests.
content: For the nearly two and a half years since Eric Adams took office as mayor of New York City, many of his fellow Democrats have kept their criticism over his management of the city relatively muted or private in deference to the mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: Cooking for One Can Be Fun, Easy and Delicious. Here’s How.
description: Making food for just yourself can feel like a burden night after night, but there are ways to make it less of a chore.
content: The new season of “The Bear” is coming soon, and one memorable scene from the last season starts with the chef Sydney Adamu, played by Ayo Edebiri, cracking a few eggs into a bowl. She then enters the meditative bliss that is making a perfect omelet. Watching her nudge the golden disk over and around a line of creamy cheese brings to mind the sandwich scene from the 2004 movie “Spanglish,” where Adam Sandler, playing a chef alone in his home kitchen after a long night at the restaurant, slides a fried egg over bacon and tomatoes shingled on a thick slice of toast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Putting New York Times Games to the Test
description: Meet some of the people who play each game and solve each puzzle before subscribers see them.
content: Getting paid to play games and solve puzzles sounds like a dream job, doesn’t it? Those who do dream about such a job probably set the possibility aside because they believe that only the most experienced solvers might qualify for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan, Robert Gebeloff and Sylvia Jarrus
title: How Gun Violence Spread Across One American City
description: Columbus, Ohio, had only about 100 homicides a year. Then came a pandemic surge. With more guns and looser laws, can the city find its way back to the old normal?
content: The sequence of events that led to the killing of Jason Keys was so confounding that friends and family did not quite believe it until they saw the video evidence played in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: The Best of ‘S.N.L.’: Trump Trolling, ‘Dune’ Buckets and Beavis Breakdowns
description: Season 49 of “Saturday Night Live” has just ended. Here’s a look back at its most memorable monologues, sketches, product parodies and impressions.
content: Season 49 of “Saturday Night Live” is barely in the history books, and everyone seems ready to turn the page to next season, when this long-running NBC sketch comedy series will tackle the 2024 presidential election and celebrate its golden anniversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Who Was Iran’s Foreign Minister, Hossein Amir Abdollahian?
description: A hard-liner and career diplomat long focused on Iran’s relationships in the Middle East, he died in a helicopter crash that also killed Iran’s president.
content: Hossein Amir Abdollahian was picked to be Iran’s foreign minister in 2021 by the president, Ebrahim Raisi, during a volatile time for Iran’s regional ties and for its relationship with the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift Beats Gunna on the Chart. Her Next Rival? Billie Eilish.
description: “The Tortured Poets Department” logs a fourth week at No. 1. Next week’s competition is a battle between two stars with multiple versions of their LPs for sale.
content: Taylor Swift stays at No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart for a fourth time, easily holding off a new release by the Atlanta rapper Gunna. But next week she may face a challenge from Billie Eilish — and its result could come down to fans’ appetites for buying multiple “versions” of the stars’ albums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is There an Alternative to the Little Black Dress?
description: Plenty of other garments can be used as the basis for simple, chic looks for a variety of occasions, our critic writes.
content: The little black dress has been regarded as a holy grail of fashion ever since Coco Chanel championed the concept back in 1926, proffering it as an alternative to the fussier, more colorful frocks popular at the time. Heralded by American Vogue, which called the little black dress the haute version of “the Ford” and declared that it would be “a sort of uniform for all women of taste,” as well as Christian Dior, who called it “essential,” it combined utilitarianism and sophistication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Red Lobster, an American Seafood Institution, Files for Bankruptcy
description: Facing challenges since the start of the pandemic, the seafood chain said it would reduce its locations and sell off most of its assets.
content: Versatile and resilient, the lobster survives by molting, shedding its skin and growing into a new, bigger shell. But eventually, energy runs low and the transformation becomes more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.5 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, a Craftsman bungalow with a guest apartment in Sacramento and a two-bedroom home with a guesthouse in San Diego.
content: This house is near the border of North Hollywood and Toluca Lake, close to the center of the NoHo Arts District, a bustling neighborhood anchored by an independent movie theater, several performing arts spaces and nightlife options, including breweries and a popular tiki bar. It is not far from the North Hollywood stop on the Metro Red Line, linking the area to Hollywood and downtown Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Iran’s President Is Not the First Leader to Die in a Helicopter Crash
description: Officials from Ukraine, Kenya and Sudan are just some of the others who have also died in crashes.
content: The president of Iran, Ebrahim Raisi, is but the latest leader to die in a helicopter crash. Mr. Raisi and Iran’s foreign minister, Hossein Amir Abdollahian, died on Sunday when the helicopter in which they were traveling went down in a mountainous area near the city of Jolfa in northwestern Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: What’s Next for Iran
description: Also, an international prosecutor’s request for arrest warrants for leaders of Israel and Hamas.
content: The Iranian authorities have aimed to project order and control after President Ebrahim Raisi and Foreign Minister Hossein Amir Abdollahian were killed in a helicopter crash. The supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said that the first vice president, Mohammad Mokhber, would assume the role of acting president and must organize elections within 50 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: At Cannes, Lily Gladstone Scores a Familiar Seat
description: The juror found herself at the center of the Kering Women in Motion dinner, a year after she was a little-known guest for “Killers of the Flower Moon.”
content: At the Cannes Film Festival, much is made of the standing ovation. Every round of applause earns breathless headlines, with outlets racing to report which movie received the most prolonged cheers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Alter
title: When Michael Cohen’s Lies Help the Case Against Trump
description: The prosecution gets some help for its theory of the crime behind the false documents.
content: Is it possible to use a lie to illuminate the truth? If the lie is told by the serial liar Michael Cohen in the right context, the answer is yes. Credit the prosecution in the Trump felony trial for pulling off this tricky maneuver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: James Greenfield, Globe-Trotting Reporter and Times Editor, Dies at 99
description: He wrote about world affairs for Time magazine and worked at the State Department before becoming a senior editor at The New York Times in 1967.
content: James L. Greenfield, an urbane journalist who covered postwar world affairs for Time magazine, served as a State Department official in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, and for nearly 25 years was a senior editor of The New York Times, died on Sunday at home in the rural town of Washington, Conn. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Liz Alderman
title: Europe Wants to Build a Stronger Defense Industry, but Can’t Decide How
description: Conflicting political visions, competitive jockeying and American dominance stand in the way of a more coordinated and efficient military machine.
content: France and Germany’s recent agreement to develop a new multibillion-dollar battlefield tank together was immediately hailed by the German defense minister, Boris Pistorius, as a “breakthrough” achievement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: Legal Weed Is Coming. It’s Time to Come Up With Some Rules.
description: Rescheduling the drug is the beginning of the end of marijuana criminalization. Now we need to think about regulation.
content: The beginning of the end of illegal weed is here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: galling
description: This word has appeared in 37 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word galling has appeared in 37 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 17 in “Goodbye, Feminist Blogs. Hello, Gen Z Content Creators?” by Emma Goldberg:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Wayne
title: Ivan F. Boesky, Rogue Trader in 1980s Wall Street Scandal, Dies at 87
description: An inspiration for the Gordon Gekko character in the movie “Wall Street,” he made a fortune from insider trading before his downfall brought a crashing end to a decade of greed.
content: Ivan F. Boesky, the brash financier who came to symbolize Wall Street greed as a central figure of the 1980s insider trading scandals, and who went to prison for his misdeeds, died on Monday at his home in the La Jolla neighborhood of San Diego. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: He Wanted to Go Back Home to the Hamptons. Could He Afford It?
description: A man who struggled to find housing in East Hampton has turned his experience into a podcast, and many of his guests are ‘navigating the waters of trying to make a living here.’
content: Ryan Sherman’s first job was picking up cigarette butts outside the restaurant where his mom worked. He was 12. A year later he started changing kegs and polishing silverware. “I was a hustler,” he said. “I always worked hard.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Cargo Ship That Crashed Into Baltimore Bridge Moves Back to Port
description: The Dali, which had been pinned under wreckage of the Francis Scott Key Bridge since late March, was refloated early Monday and returned to a berth in Baltimore.
content: Nearly eight weeks after it rammed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge, tearing down a Baltimore landmark but becoming a fixture on the horizon itself, the container ship Dali was guided on Monday by tugboats back to a berth at the Port of Baltimore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Dana Rubinstein and Michael Rothfeld
title: City Hall Aide Is Cooperating With Corruption Investigation Into Adams
description: Eric Adams’s former liaison to the Turkish community, Rana Abbasova, had knowledge of some of the mayor’s dealings with Turkish officials.
content: An aide to Mayor Eric Adams who served as his longtime liaison to the Turkish community has turned against him and is cooperating with the corruption investigation into Mr. Adams and his 2021 campaign, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Northern Lights I Did Not See
description: On this impossible, glorious planet, any creature who is tuned for beauty is sure to behold it.
content: I spend a fair amount of time looking at the sky, for the sky is nearly always full of magic. Storm clouds churning, autumn leaves flying, birds performing the never-ending miracle of flight. Often at night, I am looking for the moon. Who could fail to love the moon, magnificent in all its guises, shining coolly in all its reflected glory?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan
title: Former Trump Officials Meet in Israel With Netanyahu.
description: Robert O’Brien, one of Donald Trump’s closest foreign policy advisers, said he was there as a “private citizen.”
content: One of former President Donald J. Trump’s closest foreign policy advisers, Robert O’Brien, met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday as part of a delegation of former Trump officials that visited a number of Israeli leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Will Trump Run as a Felon? A Big 2024 Question Will Soon Be Answered.
description: The ruling in the trial of the former president and presumptive Republican nominee, which could come next week, could be a deciding factor in a tight race.
content: The witness list is winding down. Closing statements are expected early next week. Then a Manhattan jury will gather in the first criminal trial of a former president to determine whether Donald J. Trump will campaign this fall as a convicted felon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: What We Lose When ChatGPT Sounds Like Scarlett Johansson
description: OpenAI has good reason to aim for a bot voice à la the one in “Her.” But that film was about relationships. What does this real-world turn say about us?
content: When Spike Jonze’s romance “Her” was released in 2013, it sounded both like a joke — a man falls in love with his computer — and a fantasy. The iPhone was about six years old. Siri, the mildly reliable virtual assistant for that phone, came along a few years later. You could converse in a limited way with Siri, whose default female-coded voice had the timbre and tone of a self-assured middle-aged hotel concierge. She did not laugh; she did not giggle; she did not tell spontaneous jokes, only Easter egg-style gags written into her code by cheeky engineers. Siri was not your friend. She certainly wasn’t your girlfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sofia Quaglia
title: How the Cockroach Took Over the World
description: A genetic analysis of the German cockroach explained its rise in southern Asia millenniums ago, and how it eventually turned up in your kitchen.
content: They come out of hiding at night and scuttle across the house in search of starchy crumbs on the floor, a sticky sugary stain on the counter and sometimes even a nibble of toothpaste or soap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Chinese Firms Face Authoritarianism at Home and Hostility Abroad
description: The experience of TikTok’s owner, ByteDance, in Beijing and Washington shows how much the ground has shifted for China’s entrepreneurs.
content: One April afternoon in 2018, Zhang Yiming, the founder of the Beijing-based online media company ByteDance, got a notice from Chinese regulators to shut down an app where people shared jokes and silly videos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Matthew Haag
title: Robert Costello, Defense Witness in Trump Trial, Is Scolded by Judge
description: Mr. Costello tried to cast Michael D. Cohen, the witness at the heart of the prosecution’s case, as a liar, but the judge lost his patience with the witness.
content: After the prosecution rested its case against Donald J. Trump on Monday, the defense began a simple mission: destroy the credibility of the prosecution’s star witness, Michael D. Cohen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Stax: Soulsville, U.S.A.’ Review: Looking for a Little Respect
description: An HBO series tells the triumphant, tragic story of the record label Otis Redding, Isaac Hayes and the Staple Singers called home.
content: Multipart music documentaries come at us these days with the insistence and abundance of the old K-tel collections, scrambling to satisfy the cravings of every variety of pop nostalgist. Recent months have added “James Brown: Say It Loud” (A&E), “In Restless Dreams: The Music of Paul Simon” (MGM+), “Kings From Queens: The Run DMC Story” (Peacock) and “Thank You, Goodnight: The Bon Jovi Story” (Hulu), among others, to the rotation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Siyi Zhao
title: This ‘Russian Woman’ Loves China. Too Bad She’s a Deepfake.
description: A.I.-manipulated videos on Chinese sites use young, supposedly Russian women to promote China-Russia ties, stoke patriotism — and make money.
content: The woman declares, in Mandarin inflected with a slight accent, that Chinese men should marry “us Russian women.” In other videos on the Chinese short video platform Douyin, she describes how much she loves Chinese food, and hawks salt and soap from her country. “Russian people don’t trick Chinese people,” she promises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,066
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Meaghan Tobin
title: Global Tensions and a Hostile Neighbor Await Taiwan’s New Leader
description: President Lai Ching-te has pledged to stay on his predecessor’s narrow path of resisting Beijing without provoking it. It won’t be easy.
content: Taiwan’s president, Lai Ching-te, was sworn into office on Monday, vowing to keep the island democracy safe in the face of Chinese pressure and wars raging abroad that have fed uncertainty over Western staying power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Adam Goldman and Mattathias Schwartz
title: F.B.I. Shed Informants Linked to Russian Influence Operations
description: After a secret review several years ago, the bureau cut off confidential sources thought to be connected to Russian disinformation.
content: The F.B.I. cut ties to at least a handful of informants and issued warnings about dozens of others after an internal review prompted by concerns that they were linked to Russian disinformation, current and former U.S. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Does Legalizing Cannabis Increase Adolescent Use? This Expert Found Mixed Results.
description: Contrary to expectation, a major study found that weed use among minors was lower in states where the drug was legal.
content: With weed these days, it’s a Willy Wonka world: chocolate bars, lollipops, exotic-flavored gummies — to say nothing of joints, vapes, drinks and the rest. Twenty-four states and the District of Columbia have now legalized the sale of marijuana for recreational use, prompting innovation, lowering prices and making the drug — more potent than ever — more widely available. The Biden administration this week recommended easing the federal regulations on cannabis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Design Popularized by Internet ‘It’ Girls Gets a Pop-up
description: A crowd lined up in Los Angeles’s Echo Park neighborhood to buy designer Gustaf Westman’s curvy, chunky, bold objects.
content: On Saturday afternoon, the multi-hyphenate creatives of Los Angeles found a new reason to line up on Sunset Boulevard. Instead of sipping natural wine outside El Prado or waiting hours for a seat at Pijja Palace, they showed up for the designer Gustaf Westman’s pop-up shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Alan Feuer
title: A Former Leader of the Hells Angels Motorcycle Gang Joins Trump in Court
description: Chuck Zito, who did time on drug conspiracy charges, has tried to recast his persona as a general-purpose tough guy around town.
content: An entourage of more than a dozen supporters who joined President Donald J. Trump in a Manhattan courthouse on Monday included a former president of an outlaw motorcycle gang in New York City who spent years in prison on drug charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Legalized Weed Is Landing More Seniors in the E.R.
description: In Canada, cannabis poisonings rose sharply among people 65 and older after the country legalized the drug, a new study found.
content: As more places legalize marijuana, policymakers and health officials have worried about the health risks that the drug may pose to adolescents. But a new study suggests that an additional demographic is at risk: seniors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Amal Clooney Was Among the Experts Consulted on I.C.C. Warrants
description: Ms. Clooney, a prominent human rights lawyer, was on a panel that recommended arrest warrants for leaders of Israel and Hamas. She had been criticized for not speaking out on the war.
content: Amal Clooney revealed on Monday that she had reviewed the International Criminal Court prosecutor’s investigation that led to the request for arrest warrants for three Hamas leaders and two Israeli leaders, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing
title: Senate Inquiry Finds BMW Imported Cars Tied to Forced Labor in China
description: The report also found that Jaguar Land Rover and Volkswagen bought parts from a supplier the U.S. government had singled out for its practices in Xinjiang.
content: A congressional investigation found that BMW, Jaguar Land Rover and Volkswagen purchased parts that originated from a Chinese supplier flagged by the United States for participating in forced labor programs in Xinjiang, a far western region of China where the local population is subject to mass surveillance and detentions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Safety Check for OpenAI
description: Former employees of the ChatGPT maker raised concerns that it isn’t doing enough to make sure its products don’t pose a threat to humanity.
content: The tech world’s collective eyebrows rose last week when Ilya Sutskever, the OpenAI co-founder who briefly led a rebellion against Sam Altman, resigned as chief scientist. Some observers downplayed the departure, noting that Sutskever hadn’t been in the office in months and that he appeared to have left on cordial terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emile Ducke and Evelina Riabenko
title: Forced to Relive Childhood Horrors in Old Age
description: The oldest Ukrainians whose towns have been bombarded and overrun by Russia’s invasion have memories of similar miseries at the hands of Nazi Germany in World War II.
content: When she first heard that Ukraine was under attack by an invading army, Halyna Semibratska, now 101 years old, was confused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Is Biodegradable Plastic Really a Thing?
description: Technically, it exists. But here’s what to think about when shopping.
content: On the face of it, biodegradable plastic is a miracle. It looks like plastic and works much like plastic. And it goes back to nature after you throw it away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: All About Ozempic and the Next Generation of Obesity Drugs
description: How they work, what to expect when taking them and what the future holds.
content: News around drugs like Ozempic moves fast: There’s a steady drumbeat of new studies, new regulatory approvals, new shortages, new insurance hurdles. Here’s a primer on Ozempic and other popular drugs being widely used for diabetes and weight loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Biden Will Choose a New Leader for Bank Regulator With ‘Toxic’ Culture
description: Martin Gruenberg, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said he would step down once the Senate confirmed a successor.
content: President Biden plans to quickly choose a new leader to oversee the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, a bank regulator rocked by revelations of senior managers’ widespread harassment and abuse of junior employees, a White House official said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: After Raisi’s Death, Hard-Liners Are Expected to Keep Grip on Power
description: The death in a helicopter crash of Iran’s president, Ebrahim Raisi, disrupts a careful effort at a smooth transition to a new supreme leader to replace the aging Ali Khamenei.
content: The sudden death of Iran’s president, Ebrahim Raisi, opens a new chapter of instability just as the increasingly unpopular Islamic Republic is engaged in selecting its next supreme leader. Mr. Raisi, 63, had been considered a prime candidate, especially favored by the powerful Revolutionary Guards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Should Expect Little Change From Raisi’s Replacement, Experts Say
description: Israel, despite being one of Iran’s biggest foes, saw little strategic benefit from the president’s death and was not likely to change its posture toward Tehran, analysts said.
content: After President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran was killed in a helicopter crash, Israeli officials quickly dismissed suggestions that they were behind his death, which Iranian state news media said was the result of “technical failure.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Alter
title: A Tongue-Lashing for a Defense Witness Isn’t Great News for Trump
description: The witness tried to play judge, and the real judge was not pleased.
content: Eight times a day during his felony trial, a former president of the United States must stand and honor 12 jurors and six alternates as they walk past, eyes straight ahead or down, casting no glances at him. It’s inspiring to watch these ordinary citizens as sovereign soldiers for justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louis Bayard
title: Who Was Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy, Really?
description: In “Once Upon a Time,” Elizabeth Beller examines the life and death of the woman who was best known for marrying John F. Kennedy Jr.
content: One of the many reasons to wish that Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy were alive and well is that, without too much urging, she might have formed a sorority with Meghan Markle. They could have talked about what it’s like to be a woman thrust into a brutal family dynasty and a Hobbesian press ecosystem. Maybe they would have exchanged tips for dodging paparazzi. Maybe, over enough drinks, they would have asked each other if their husbands were worth all the trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Threats and Fear Are Transforming U.S. Politics
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 20, 2024.
content: “These attacks are not coming from people who are looking for solutions. They’re looking for confrontation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: This Job Training Program Wants Payback From Students
description: Pursuit, a nonprofit in Queens, requires those who get jobs to pay it 5 percent to 15 percent of their earnings for four years.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at an innovative nonprofit that trains low-income workers to become software engineers — and tangled with a state agency that threatened a cease-and-desist order and possibly criminal prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Jillian Rayfield
title: Dublin-New York Portal Reopens After Flashing and Other Shenanigans
description: After closing because of questionable behavior last week, a video connection between Ireland and New York City is back on. Crowds rejoiced — in Dublin, anyway.
content: The Portal is back. For now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
title: Iran Moves to Project Stability After Crash Kills Key Leaders
description: The ayatollah announced five days of mourning for the president and foreign minister who died when their helicopter plunged into a mountainous region. Some Iranians celebrated the deaths.
content: Iran sought to project a sense of order and control on Monday by quickly naming an acting president and foreign minister a day after a helicopter crash killed both leaders. The change in leadership came at a time of heightened tensions in the Middle East and domestic discontent in Iran, where many residents have called for an end to decades of repressive clerical rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Doctors Are Still Figuring Out Adult A.D.H.D.
description: It’s one of the most common psychiatric disorders in adults. Yet there are no U.S. guidelines for diagnosing and treating patients beyond childhood.
content: Just before Katie Marsh dropped out of college, she began to worry that she might have attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Steinberger, Rob Szypko, Mooj Zadie, Sydney Harper, Luke Vander Ploeg, Marc Georges, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Alyssa Moxley
title: Was the 401(k) a Mistake?
description: Much of why Americans are retiring with so little money can be traced to the reliance on the retirement account.
content: The first generation to be fully reliant on 401(k) plans is now starting to retire. As that happens, it is becoming clear just how broken the system is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Zoellner
title: Ruben Gallego and the Fight for Arizona
description: The Grand Canyon State is up for grabs — and so is its political future.
content: Arizona has become an epicenter of political discord and conflict over issues that have roiled the national discourse. In the fall, the outrage over an abortion ban from 1864 and a potential ballot initiative on the issue are likely to motivate Democrats, and the outrage over chaos at the border is likely to motivate Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: Who Is Karim Khan, the I.C.C. Prosecutor?
description: Mr. Khan, known as a gifted speaker and a tough-minded litigator, took an unusual approach to announcing his request for arrest warrants for leaders of Hamas and Israel.
content: Karim Khan, the International Criminal Court prosecutor who announced on Monday that he would apply for arrest warrants for leaders of Israel and Hamas, has gained a reputation over a long career in international law as a gifted speaker and a tough-minded litigator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Assange Can Appeal Extradition to U.S., British Court Rules
description: The WikiLeaks founder won his bid to appeal his extradition to the United States on espionage charges, opening a new chapter in a prolonged legal battle.
content: A London court ruled on Monday that Julian Assange, the embattled WikiLeaks founder, could appeal his extradition to the United States, a move that opens a new chapter in his prolonged fight against being sent to America to face trial on espionage charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: The Author of ‘Crazy Rich Asians’ Can’t Go Home, Except in His Books
description: Kevin Kwan left Singapore’s opulent, status-obsessed, upper crust when he was 11. He’s still writing about it.
content: A reader of Kevin Kwan’s books could be forgiven for expecting him to make a grand entrance at lunch in Beverly Hills — in a Lamborghini, perhaps, or wearing a slick pair of shades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Ebrahim Raisi, Iran’s President, Dies in Helicopter Crash at 63
description: The hard-line Shiite cleric was seen as a possible successor to Iran’s supreme leader. Mr. Raisi’s death comes at a moment of turbulence for a country facing a deepening conflict with Israel.
content: Ebrahim Raisi, Iran’s president and a top contender to succeed the nation’s supreme leader, was killed on Sunday in a helicopter crash. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: She Helped Wage the Fight for $15. Where Will Labor Go After Her?
description: Low-wage workers owe a lot to Mary Kay Henry.
content: Mary Kay Henry had one big success and one big disappointment in her 14 years as president of the Service Employees International Union, which is one of the biggest and most politically powerful in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: U.S. ‘Condolences’ for Raisi Reflect a Delicate Diplomatic Ritual
description: Whether it’s Stalin or Castro or Kim Jong-il, the United States struggles for the right words when a reviled foreign strongman dies.
content: In the eyes of the Biden administration, Ebrahim Raisi was a brutal tyrant, a sworn enemy and a threat to world peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden says there is ‘no equivalence between Israel and Hamas.’
description: The president, s
content: President Biden said flatly on Monday that Israel’s military assault in Gaza in the wake of the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks “is not genocide.” “We reject that,” he said, telling an audience of Jewish leaders and activists that Americans “stand with Israel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Sexual Assault Suit Against Neil Portnow, Ex-Grammys Chief, Is Dismissed
description: The plaintiff, who had filed her suit anonymously, told a judge that she feared the consequences if efforts to reveal her name during the proceeding were successful.
content: A federal judge has dismissed a sexual assault lawsuit against the former head of the Grammy Awards, after the plaintiff fell out with her lawyers and said in court papers that she feared for her safety and well-being if her real name were revealed during the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Courtroom Plays Host to Nonstop Spectacle as Prosecution Rests
description: Michael D. Cohen admitted stealing from the Trump Organization. The judge excoriated a defense witness. And Donald J. Trump’s entourage included a former leader of the Hells Angels.
content: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush-money trial in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Graduate Students at U.C. Santa Cruz to Strike on Monday
description: The student workers’ union says the University of California’s handling of Israel-Hamas war protests may soon prompt walkouts at several campuses.
content: Protests over the Israel-Hamas war have rattled college campuses for weeks across California and across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: N.Y.C. Parents Rebuked for Questioning Transgender Student-Athlete Rules
description: Over a dozen Democratic elected officials criticized a parent group that asked for a review of rules that let students play on sports teams that align with their gender identity.
content: This spring, a group of elected parent leaders in New York asked the city to review education department rules allowing transgender students to play on sports teams that align with their gender identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: She Survived a Train Accident. Her Train Wreck of a Dad Is Next.
description: In Garth Risk Hallberg’s new novel, a teenage rebel and her father reconnect amid a sea of their own troubles.
content: Garth Risk Hallberg’s ambitious but uneven and exhausting new novel, “The Second Coming,” takes its title from an unreleased live album by Prince. One of the book’s central characters, a 13-year-old girl named Jolie Aspern, is on a Manhattan subway platform listening to a bootleg version when her phone slips from her hand and clatters onto the tracks below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Ocasio-Cortez Backs N.Y. Bill Limiting Donations to Israeli Settlements
description: Under the bill, New York nonprofits that provide financial support to Israel’s military or settlements could be sued for at least $1 million and lose their tax-exempt status.
content: A long-shot effort by left-leaning New York state lawmakers to curtail financial support for Israeli settlements has drawn a big-name backer — but she doesn’t have a vote in Albany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: South Africa’s Highest Court Says Jacob Zuma Can’t Serve in Parliament
description: With elections just over a week away, the political comeback of the former president has presented a major test for the country’s young democracy.
content: South Africa’s highest court on Monday ruled that former President Jacob Zuma was not eligible to serve in Parliament, a decision that may deepen political turmoil in the country just over a week before a crucial national election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Penguin Random House Dismisses Two of Its Top Publishers
description: The departures of Reagan Arthur, who led Alfred A. Knopf, and Lisa Lucas, who held the top job at Pantheon and Schocken, came as a surprise to many in the company.
content: In a significant shake up, Penguin Random House, the largest publishing house in the United States, announced on Monday that the publishers of two of its most prestigious literary imprints had been let go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Abbott Elementary’ and ‘The Good Doctor’
description: The ABC comedy wraps up its third season. The medical show airs its series finale.
content: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, May 20-26. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Trump Media Reports Lackluster Revenues and Large Losses
description: The former president’s social media company reported taking in $770,000 in advertising revenue in the first quarter, sharply down from the year-earlier period.
content: On Monday, former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company reported taking in $770,000 in advertising revenue in the first three months of the year, largely from its Truth Social platform, as it continued to incur hefty losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Kaye
title: With I.C.C. Arrest Warrants, Let Justice Take Its Course
description: The request for International Criminal Court arrest warrants promotes the idea that the basic rules of international humanitarian law apply to all.
content: In seeking the arrests of senior leaders of Israel and Hamas, the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court has given the world a promise of accountability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lewis Gordon
title: The Painstaking Quest to Portray a Tortured Warrior
description: For the hyperrealistic visuals in the video game Senua’s Saga: Hellblade II, the studio traveled to Iceland, took thousands of photos and spent months on motion capture.
content: They arrive unexpectedly, flickering moments that make you unsure if you are peering at a video game or the real world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Trump Trial’s Great Anticlimax
description: A strange sense of anticlimax hangs over the Trump trial.
content: If I’d pictured Donald Trump’s first criminal trial a few years ago, I’d have imagined the biggest, splashiest story in the world. Instead, as we lurch toward a verdict that could brand the presumptive Republican nominee a felon and possibly even send him to prison, a strange sense of anticlimax hangs over the whole affair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Trump’s Eyes Wide Shut Strategy
description: The prosecution rested its case. And Trump rested his eyes.
content: There are a lot of rules in Courtroom 1530 inside the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building, many of which are posted next to the swinging entry doors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Taking the Long Way Home From Alaska
description: On an epic road trip, a family plots a course from Alaska to the Lower 48, passing through some of Canada’s most spectacular scenery. The tally: 2,200 miles, five national parks, numerous hot springs and one excellent reindeer hot dog.
content: Within months of the Pearl Harbor bombing on Dec. 7, 1941, the United States, in cooperation with the Canadian authorities, set out to build a highway from British Columbia to Alaska, then a territory and viewed as vulnerable to attack by Japan. The original 1,685-mile road took more than 10,000 soldiers less than nine months to complete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Farnaz Fassihi, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Iran’s President Dies, and Warrants Sought for Israel, Hamas Leaders
description: Plus, the Trump trial enters its final days.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Schweber
title: Hecklers Drown Out Trump’s Backers With Cowbells and Whistles
description: A contingent of supporters of the former president came to speak across from the courthouse, but they were inaudible.
content: Donald J. Trump has been joined in recent days by entourages of supporters who watch his prosecution in the morning and then give statements backing him outside the courthouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: A High-Stress Countdown Begins
description: The prosecution rested its case and closing arguments are expected to begin next week.
content: For many Americans, the Memorial Day break will mean barbecues, flag-draped parades and the glory of a three-day weekend. But for those centrally involved in the criminal trial of Donald Trump — including the defendant — it will be an anxious countdown to the culmination of the first trial of an American president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: She Wants to Make San Francisco Ballet an ‘Arrow to the Future’
description: Tamara Rojo, the company’s new artistic director, has a vision of ballet as for the people — all the people — with dances that reflect our world.
content: Coming from Tamara Rojo, three words go a long way: “That, I believe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: Is Curbside Parking an Endangered Species?
description: City officials and others are reconsidering how New Yorkers store their cars.
content: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: How Did You Grow and Change This School Year?
description: In this forum, we invite both students and teachers to reflect on their challenges and successes — and to consider how to build on them for next year.
content: The 2023-24 academic year is coming to a close, and we have a post describing 10 ways to reflect on these last months and learn from them. But the 10 ways aren’t just for students — we also hope teachers can benefit from them. In fact, we would be delighted if teachers and students did some of the exercises together and told us what happened!
source.name: The New York Times

title: Israel and Gaza: Despair and What-Ifs
description: Readers disagree about a guest essay by Megan K. Stack. Also: Big politics in politics; “journey” as metaphor; helping the mentally ill and homeless.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Michael Emerson Still Reigns as TV’s King of Creepy
description: The actor has played unsettling men on shows like “Lost” and “Fallout.” In the new season of “Evil,” he might be raising the Antichrist.
content: On one wall of the actor Michael Emerson’s Manhattan apartment hangs a large self portrait he drew about 40 years ago. In the intentionally distorted image, Emerson peers out menacingly from behind his circular glasses. His wife, the actor Carrie Preston, thinks it serves as a fitting summation of his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Senate to Vote Again on Border Deal as Democrats Seek Political Edge
description: The bipartisan border enforcement compromise, blocked by Republicans in February, is all but certain to be thwarted again. Democrats aim to tag the G.O.P. as the culprit in its failure.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the majority leader, plans to push forward this week with a second vote on a bipartisan border enforcement bill that Senate Republicans killed earlier this year at the urging of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Schweber
title: Outside the Trump Trial: Sock Puppets, Sex Pills and Smutty Balloons
description: The city serves up a cast of supporting characters who flock to a park outside Manhattan Criminal Court, where Donald Trump is on trial, and grab the spotlight.
content: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush-money trial in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
title: Fraud Trial to Begin for Ozy Founder Carlos Watson
description: Mr. Watson’s lawyer has argued that many other media leaders lured investors with “puffing and bluffing,” and that Mr. Watson is being singled out because he is Black.
content: The 2010s were a frothy time for digital publishing. Billions of dollars flowed into publishers like BuzzFeed and Vice, with big media companies and venture capitalists betting those start-ups would eventually make lots of money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Fiery, Tingly Kung Pao Tofu
description: More fast, flavorful dinners: miso-honey chicken and asparagus; roasted salmon with pea pesto; sheet-pan meatballs with tomatoes and broccoli.
content: With its piney slap and mouth-numbing tingle, the Sichuan peppercorn lends a distinct and irresistible character to many dishes from that region. Yet from 1968 to 2005 it was actually illegal to import it to the United States, because it was thought that the dried prickly ash berry (the Sichuan peppercorn) might carry a bacterial disease that threatens citrus trees. During that dark time, American versions of dishes like kung pao chicken simply left out the spice, replacing its pungency and heat with extra red chiles and ginger. Tasty, sure. But tingly? Not so much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: In a House Race in N.H., a Famous Spouse, and a Traumatic Pregnancy
description: Maggie Tamposi Goodlander, the wife of the national security adviser, is navigating a personal landscape with little precedent in her run for Congress in New Hampshire.
content: Maggie Tamposi Goodlander gave birth to her stillborn son in a hotel bathtub on Easter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy White
title: See How Easily A.I. Chatbots Can Be Taught to Spew Disinformation
description: Ahead of the election this year, the results suggested how easy it could be to create divisive content online, on either side of the political spectrum.
content: Ahead of the election this year, the results suggested how easy it could be to create divisive content online, on either side of the political spectrum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know the Literary Influences of These Animated Films?
description: Several 21st-century movies were inspired by popular literature that is much older. Try this short quiz to see how many books and films you recognize.
content: Several 21st-century movies were inspired by popular literature that is much older. Try this short quiz to see how many books and films you recognize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr, Shakked Auerbach, Mark Boyer and Daniel Bateman
title: Proud to Serve Israel, but Not Its Government
description: Some reservists in the Israel Defense Forces who have returned home from war have joined the growing calls within Israel for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his right-wing coalition to step aside.
content: Some reservists in the Israel Defense Forces who have returned home from war have joined the growing calls within Israel for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his right-wing coalition to step aside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: I.C.C. Prosecutor Asks for Warrants for Netanyahu and Hamas Leaders
description: The International Criminal Court prosecutor said he believed Hamas leaders and Israeli leaders, including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yahya Sinwar of Hamas, were responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity.
content: The International Criminal Court prosecutor said he believed Hamas leaders and Israeli leaders, including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yahya Sinwar of Hamas, were responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Storyful
title: Comet Fragment Flashes in the Night Sky Over Spain and Portugal
description: A bright object broke up in Earth’s atmosphere on Saturday night, illuminating night skies over parts of Spain and Portugal. Experts say it was a fragment of a comet, perhaps only a few feet in size.
content: A bright object broke up in Earth’s atmosphere on Saturday night, illuminating night skies over parts of Spain and Portugal. Experts say it was a fragment of a comet, perhaps only a few feet in size.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By AFP, The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Rescuers Find Helicopter Carrying Iran’s President
description: After scouring a mountainous area of dense forest, rescuers found the remains of the aircraft, which had the president and foreign minister on board.
content: After scouring a mountainous area of dense forest, rescuers found the remains of the aircraft, which had the president and foreign minister on board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Says Israeli Military Assault in Gaza Is ‘Not Genocide’
description: At a celebration of Jewish Heritage Month, President Biden pledged support to Israel and condemned a decision by the prosecutor for the International Criminal Court to seek arrest warrants for top Israeli officials.
content: At a celebration of Jewish Heritage Month, President Biden pledged support to Israel and condemned a decision by the prosecutor for the International Criminal Court to seek arrest warrants for top Israeli officials.
source.name: The New York Times
